docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Consider two metric spaces \((\boldsymbol{X},d_{\boldsymbol{X}})\) and \((\boldsymbol{Y},d_{\boldsymbol{Y}})\text{,}\) and a function \(\boldsymbol{f}\colon \boldsymbol{E}\to\boldsymbol{Y}\) where \(\boldsymbol{E}\subseteq\boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\) Let \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\in\boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\) Assume there exists an \(r>0\) such that \(\boldsymbol{B}_{(\boldsymbol{X},d_{\boldsymbol{X}})}(\boldsymbol{x}_0,r)\subseteq \boldsymbol{E}\text{.}\) We say that \(\boldsymbol{f}\) is continuous at \(\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}_0\) if, for any \(\varepsilon > 0\text{,}\) there exists a \(0<\delta \leq r\) such that whenever \(d_{\boldsymbol{X}}(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{x}_0)<\delta\text{,}\) we have \(d_{\boldsymbol{Y}}(\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}),\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0))<\varepsilon\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• If one path approaching the point has a different limit, then the function's limit at that point does not exist, and therefore the function is not continuous at that point.
  • A vector-valued function is continuous if and only if each of its component functions is continuous.
  • Most properties of real-valued functions of one real variable are preserved under continuity. In particular, continuity is preserved under addition, subtraction, multiplication, division (where the denominator is nonzero), as well as taking the maximum, minimum, and composition of functions.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Given a metric space \((\boldsymbol{X}, d)\), a sequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_{i})_{i=1}^\infty\) and a point \(\boldsymbol{x}\) in \(\boldsymbol{X}\), the sequence is said to converge to \(\boldsymbol{x}\) under metric \(\boldsymbol{d}\) if \(\displaystyle \lim_{i\to\infty}d(\boldsymbol{x}_i, \boldsymbol{x}) = 0\).

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • A convergent sequence in a metric space must be a Cauchy sequence.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The sequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_{i})_{i=1}^\infty\) where \(\boldsymbol{x}_i = (1/i, 1/i)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) converges to \((0,0)\) under the Euclidean metric \(d_2\).
  • The sequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_{i})_{i=1}^\infty\) where \(\boldsymbol{x}_i = (1/i, 1/i)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) also converges to \((0,0)\) under the taxicab metric \(d_1\).

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text:
Consider a power series \(\displaystyle f(x)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\) with a radius of convergence \(R > 0\text{.}\) For any chosen \(r\) such that \(0 < r < R\):

  • The series converges pointwise on the open interval \((a-R, a+R)\text{.}\)
  • It converges uniformly on the closed interval \([a-r, a+r]\text{.}\)
  • The limiting function \(f\) is differentiable on \((a-R, a+R)\text{.}\)
  • The derivative series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty nc_n (x-a)^{n-1}\) converges uniformly to the derivative, \(f'\text{,}\) on \([a-r, a+r]\text{.}\)

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty n(-2)^n (x-3)^n\) with \(R = 1/2\) centered at \(a = 3\text{,}\) converges pointwise on \((5/2, 7/2)\) and uniformly on any closed interval within it.
  • The series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^{n^2} (x+2)^n\) with \(R = 0\) centered at \(a = -2\text{,}\) converges solely at its center \(x = -2\text{.}\)
  • The series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^{-n^2} (x+2)^n\) with \(R = +\infty\) centered at \(a = -2\text{,}\) converges pointwise over the entire real line \(\mathbb{R}\text{.}\) Uniform convergence for this series over \(\mathbb{R}\) needs further analysis.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Consider a (topological) space \(\boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\) Let \(\boldsymbol{E}\) be a subset of \(\boldsymbol{X}\text{,}\) and let \(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{C}}=\{\boldsymbol{G}_i\colon i\in I\}\) be a collection of subsets \(\boldsymbol{G}_i\) of \(\boldsymbol{X}\) indexed by an arbitrary index set \(I\text{.}\) \(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{C}}\) is called a cover of \(\boldsymbol{E}\) if \(\displaystyle \boldsymbol{E} \subseteq \bigcup_{i\in I} \boldsymbol{G}_i\text{.}\)

  • An open cover is a cover where each "patch" \(\boldsymbol{G}_i\) is open.
  • A finite cover consists of a collection \(\{\boldsymbol{G}_i\colon i\in I\}\) where \(I\) is finite. A cover is called a countable cover when \(I\) is a countable set, e.g., \(\mathbb{N}\text{.}\)
  • A subcover is a cover that is a subset of another cover.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
The Euclidean norm of a vector \(\boldsymbol{x}=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is:

\[ \|\boldsymbol{x}\|_2=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_i^2}. \]

The Euclidean distance between points \(\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) and \(\boldsymbol y=(y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is:

\[ d_2(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y)=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-x_i)^2}. \]

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • When Euclidean space is represented by a Cartesian coordinate system, Euclidean distance satisfies the Pythagorean relation.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \(\boldsymbol V\) be a real vector space with \(\dim \boldsymbol V<\infty\). If \(V\) has an inner product \(\left\langle\cdot.\cdot\right\rangle\colon \boldsymbol V\times \boldsymbol V\to\mathbb R\), then \((\boldsymbol V,\left\langle\cdot.\cdot\right\rangle)\) is a Euclidean space. In practice, the real coordinate space \(\mathbb R^n\) equipped with the standard inner product denotes the \(n\)-dimensional Euclidean space.

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: A Euclidean space is a real finite-dimensional inner product space.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • In a Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\), the inner product induces a norm given by \(\displaystyle \|\boldsymbol x\| = \sqrt{\langle \boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol x\rangle} = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2}.\) The metric induced by this norm is defined as \(\displaystyle d(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y) = \|\boldsymbol x-\boldsymbol y\| = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2},\) which is precisely the Euclidean distance.

docs.title: 📘 Definition

Consider a function \(\boldsymbol f\colon \boldsymbol X \to\boldsymbol Y\) where \(\boldsymbol X\) is set in an \(n\)-dimensional space (e.g., \(\mathbb R^n\)) and \(\boldsymbol Y\) in an \(k\)-dimensional space (e.g., \(\mathbb R^k\)). We have the following terminologies:

  • it is called a univariate function (also known as single variable function, function of one variable) if \(n=1\);
  • it is called a bivariate function (also known as function of two variables) if \(n=2\);
  • it is called a multivariable function (also known as multivariate function, function of several variables) if \(n\geq 2\);
  • it is called a real-valued function if its codomain is a subset of \(\mathbb R\);
  • it is called a vector-valued function if \(k\geq 2\).

docs.text: Let \(a < b\) be real numbers, and consider a function \(f\colon [a, b] \to \mathbb{R}\) that is continuous on \([a, b]\text{.}\) Then, \(f\) is uniformly continuous on \([a, b]\text{.}\)

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation

  • This prevents sudden jumps or unbounded growth, ensuring that the function's small changes near one point apply uniformly across the whole interval.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \(n,\,k \in\mathbb N^+\) and \(m\in \mathbb Z\). A function \(\boldsymbol f\colon \mathbb R^n\to \mathbb R^k\) is homogeneous of degree \(\boldsymbol m\) if $$ \boldsymbol f(cx_1,\,cx_2,\,\dots,\,cx_n)=c^m \boldsymbol f(x_1,\,x_2,\,\dots,\,x_n) $$ for every \((x_1,\,x_2,\,\dots,\,x_n)\) and \(c\neq 0\).

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: If each of the homogeneous function's arguments is multiplied by the same scalar, then the function's value is multiplied by some power of this scalar.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(f(x,y) = x^2 + y^2 + xy\) is homogeneous as \(f(cx, cy) = c^2 f(x,y)\).
  • \(g(x,y) = xy + x\) is said to be inhomogeneous.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Let \(\boldsymbol{X}\) and \(\boldsymbol{Y}\) be two sets in metric spaces, and let \(\boldsymbol{f}\colon \boldsymbol{X}\to\boldsymbol{Y}\) be a function. Let \(\boldsymbol{C}\) be a subset of the domain \(\boldsymbol{X}\), the image of \(\boldsymbol{C}\) under \(\boldsymbol{f}\) is defined as:

\[ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{C})=\{\boldsymbol{y}\in\boldsymbol{Y}\colon \text{there exists some } \boldsymbol{x}\in\boldsymbol{C} \text{ such that } \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})\}. \]

Let \(\boldsymbol{V}\) be a subset of the codomain \(\boldsymbol{Y}\), the preimage of \(\boldsymbol{V}\) under \(\boldsymbol{f}\) includes all points in the domain that give results in \(\boldsymbol{V}\):

\[ \boldsymbol{f}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{V})=\{\boldsymbol{x}\in\boldsymbol{X}\colon\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})\in\boldsymbol{V}\}. \]

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• \(\boldsymbol{V}\) only needs to be a part of the codomain of \(\boldsymbol{f}\). This means there might be some \(\boldsymbol{y}\) in \(\boldsymbol{V}\) that doesn't match any \(\boldsymbol{x}\) in the domain \(\boldsymbol{X}\).
  • We have \(\boldsymbol{C} \subseteq \boldsymbol{f}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{C}))\) and \(\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{f}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{V})) \subseteq \boldsymbol{V}\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: The imaginary unit, symbolized as \(\mathrm{i}\), is characterized by its square being \(-1\), i.e., \(\mathrm{i}^2 = -1.\)

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text:
The imaginary unit \(\mathrm{i}\) is a solution, not the solution, to the equation \(x^2+1=0\) since \(-\mathrm{i}\) is also a solution.

The choice of \(\mathrm{i}\) over \(-\mathrm{i}\) as the "principal" square root of \(-1\) is largely a matter of convention, similar to how we choose the positive square root of a positive number as its principal square root.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text: • \(\mathrm{i}^3 = \mathrm{i}^2 \cdot\mathrm{i} = (-1) \cdot \mathrm{i} = -\mathrm{i}, \quad \mathrm{i}^4 = \mathrm{i}^3 \cdot \mathrm{i} = (-\mathrm{i})\cdot \mathrm{i} = 1, \quad \mathrm{i}^5 = \mathrm{i}^4 \cdot \mathrm{i} =\mathrm{i}.\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Consider a sequence of functions \((f_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) from \(X\) to \(\mathbb{R}\text{.}\) If the sequence of partial sums \(\displaystyle S_N(x) = \sum_{n=1}^N f_n(x)\) converges to \(f\colon X \to \mathbb{R}\) pointwise or uniformly on \(X\) as \(N \to \infty\text{,}\) then we say the infinite series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n\) converges pointwise/uniformly to \(\boldsymbol{f}\) on \(\boldsymbol{X}\text{,}\) denoted as \(\displaystyle f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n(x)\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• If \(f_n\)'s are (continuously) differentiable, \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n \rightarrow f\text{,}\) and \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty f'_n\rightrightarrows g\) on \((a,b)\text{,}\) then \(f\) is (continuously) differentiable on \((a, b)\) with \(f' = g\text{,}\) i.e.,
\[ \sum_{n=1}^\infty f'_n(x_0)=\left(\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n\right)'(x_0),\quad x_0\in(a,b). \]
  • If \(f_n\)'s are Riemann integrable, and the series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n\) converges uniformly on \(X\text{,}\) then the series is Riemann integrable, and $$ \int_X \left(\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n(x)\right) \, \mathrm{d}x = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \int_X f_n(x) \, \mathrm{d}x. $$

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Let \(\boldsymbol V\) be a vector space over a field \(\mathbb{F}\), where \(\mathbb{F} = \mathbb{R}\) or \(\mathbb{C}\). An inner product on \(\boldsymbol V\) is a function \(\langle \cdot , \cdot \rangle : \boldsymbol V \times \boldsymbol V \to \mathbb{F}\) such that for all \(x,y,z \in \boldsymbol V\) and all \(\alpha,\beta \in \mathbb{F}\), the following properties hold:

  1. Conjugate symmetry: $$ \langle \boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y \rangle = \overline{\langle \boldsymbol y,\boldsymbol x \rangle}. $$

  2. Linearity in the first argument: $$ \langle \alpha \boldsymbol x + \beta \boldsymbol y, \boldsymbol z \rangle = \alpha \langle \boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol z \rangle + \beta \langle \boldsymbol y,\boldsymbol z \rangle. $$

  3. Positive-definiteness: $$ \langle \boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol x \rangle > 0 \quad \text{for all } \boldsymbol x \neq \boldsymbol 0. $$

The pair \((\boldsymbol V,\langle \cdot , \cdot \rangle)\) is called an inner product space.

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: Inner products allow formal definitions of intuitive geometric notions, such as lengths, angles, and orthogonality (zero inner product) of vectors.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• The norm \(\|\cdot\|\colon \boldsymbol V\to [0,+\infty)\) in an inner product space is defined as \(\|\boldsymbol x\|=\sqrt{\langle \boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol x \rangle}\).
  • The distance \(d\colon \boldsymbol{V}\times\boldsymbol{V}\to[0,+\infty)\) in an inner product space is defined as \(d(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y)=\sqrt{\|\boldsymbol x-\boldsymbol y\|}.\)

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The standard inner product on \(\mathbb R^n\) is the dot product which is defined by $$ \boldsymbol x\cdot \boldsymbol y=x_1y_1+x_2y_2+\cdots+x_ny_n. $$
  • More generally, a function \(\langle \cdot , \cdot \rangle\) is an inner product on \(\mathbb R^n\) if and only if there exists a symmetric positive-definite matrix \(\boldsymbol M\) such that \(\langle \boldsymbol x , \boldsymbol y \rangle=\boldsymbol x^\intercal \boldsymbol M\boldsymbol y\) for all \(\boldsymbol x , \boldsymbol y\in\mathbb R^n\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: For a metric space \((\boldsymbol{X},d)\text{,}\) and a subset \(\boldsymbol{E} \subseteq \boldsymbol{X}\text{,}\) a point \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) is an interior point of \(\boldsymbol{E}\) if there exists some \(\varepsilon > 0\) such that \(\boldsymbol{B}(\boldsymbol{x}_0,\varepsilon) \subseteq \boldsymbol{E}\text{.}\) We denote the set of interior points of \(\boldsymbol{E}\) as \(\mathrm{int} \boldsymbol{E}\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• An interior point \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) of \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is always in \(\boldsymbol{E}\) since balls centered at \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) include \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\text{.}\)
  • The interior of \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is the largest open subset of \(\boldsymbol{E}\).

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text: Let \(f\colon \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous real-valued function. Let \(\boldsymbol{E}\) be any connected subset of \(\mathbb{R}^n\text{,}\) and let \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\) be any two points in \(\boldsymbol{E}\text{.}\) If \(y\) is a real number between \(f(\boldsymbol{a})\) and \(f(\boldsymbol{b})\text{,}\) then there exists a \(\boldsymbol{c} \in \boldsymbol{E}\) such that \(f(\boldsymbol{c}) = y\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Let \(\boldsymbol{f}\colon \boldsymbol{X} \to \mathbb R\) be a real-valued function defined on a set \(\boldsymbol{X}\subseteq \mathbb R^n\). A level set is defined as the preimage of a singleton set \(\{k\}\), i.e.,

\[ L_k(f)=f^{-1}(\{k\})=\{(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\in\mathbb{R}^n\colon f(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)=k\}. \]

When the number of independent variables is two, a level set is called a level curve, also known as contour line.

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: A level curve is the set of all real-valued solutions of an equation in two variables \(x_1\) and \(x_2\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \((a_n)_{n=0}^{\infty}\) be a sequence. For each \(N\in\mathbb{N}\text{,}\) consider the supremum and infimum of the terms from \(a_N\) onward: \(\displaystyle s_N = \sup_{n\geq N} a_n\) and \(\displaystyle i_N = \inf_{n\geq N} a_n\text{.}\) The limit superior and limit inferior of \((a_n)_{n=0}^{\infty}\) are defined as: $$ \begin{aligned} \limsup_{n\to \infty}a_n &:= \lim_{N\to\infty} s_N = \inf_{N\geq 0} s_N=\inf_{N\geq 0}\sup_{n\geq N} a_n, \ \liminf_{n\to \infty}a_n &:= \lim_{N\to\infty} i_N = \sup_{N\geq 0} i_N=\sup_{N\geq 0}\inf_{n\geq N} a_n. \end{aligned} $$

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• The limit superior and limit inferior of a sequence always exist.
  • A sequence converges if and only if its \(\limsup\) and \(\liminf\) are equal and finite; otherwise, it's divergent.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• For \(a_n = (-1)^n\): \(\limsup\limits_{n\to \infty}a_n = 1\text{,}\) \(\liminf\limits_{n\to \infty}a_n = -1\text{.}\)
  • For \(a_n = 1/2^n\): \(\limsup\limits_{n\to \infty}a_n = \liminf\limits_{n\to \infty}a_n = 0\text{.}\)

Let \(n,\,k \in\mathbb N^+\), and let \(\boldsymbol A=\mathbb R^{k\times n}\) be \(k\times n\) real-valued matrix.

In particular, a linear real-valued function \(f\colon \mathbb R^n\to \mathbb R\) has the general expression $$ f(x_1,\,x_2,\,\dots,\,x_n)=a_1x_1+a_2x_2+\cdots+c_nx_n+b. $$

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: If one argument of a linear function is increased by \(c\) units, the function value changes by a constant multiple of \(c\) units.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \(n,\,k \in\mathbb N^+\). A function \(\boldsymbol{f}\colon \mathbb{R}^n\to \mathbb{R}^k\) is termed a linear transformation if it is a homogeneous linear function. In particular, when \(k=1\), a linear transformation has the general expression $$ f(x_1,\,x_2,\,\dots,\,x_n)=a_1x_1+a_2x_2+\cdots+c_nx_n. $$

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: A linear transformation upholds vector addition and scalar multiplication, e.g., for any \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n\) and \(c \in \mathbb{R}\), it holds: $$ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{y}) = \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) + \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{y}), \quad \boldsymbol{f}(c\boldsymbol{x}) = c\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}), $$

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • The graph of a linear transformation from \(\mathbb R^n\) to \(\mathbb R\) is a hyperplane of dimension \(n\) that goes through the origin.

docs.title: 📌 Proposition
docs.text:
Let the origin be an interior point of \(E\subseteq \mathbb{R}\text{,}\) and let \(f\colon E\to\mathbb{R}\) be real analytic at \(x=0\text{.}\) Then \(f\) has the power series expansion around \(x=0\):

\[ f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{f^{(n)}(0)}{n!} x^n \quad \text{for all } x \in (-r,r), \]

known as the Maclaurin series of \(f\).

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: The Maclurin series of \(f\) is exactly the Taylor series of \(f\) at the origin.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
The maximum norm of \(\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) in an \(n\)-dimensional real coordinate space \(\mathbb R^n\) with fixed Cartesian coordinate system is:

\[ \|\boldsymbol x\|_\infty=\max_{1\leq i\leq n}|x_i|. \]

Correspondingly, the Chebyshev distance between \(\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) and \(\boldsymbol y=(y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n)\) is calculated as:

\[ d_\infty(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y)=\max_{1\leq i\leq n}|x_i-y_i|. \]

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: The maximum norm is the limiting case of the \(p\)-norm when \(p\to+\infty\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
A metric space \((\boldsymbol{X}, d)\) consists of a set of points \(\boldsymbol{X}\) and a distance function (or metric) \(d\colon \boldsymbol{X} \times \boldsymbol{X} \to [0,+\infty)\) that maps pairs of points to nonnegative real values. The metric adheres to the following properties:

  1. Non-negativity: \(d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) \geq 0\) for any \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\)
  2. Identity of indiscernibles: \(d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) = 0\) if and only if \(\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{y}\text{.}\)
  3. Symmetry: \(d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) = d(\boldsymbol{y},\boldsymbol{x})\) for any \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\)
  4. Triangle inequality: \(d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{z}) \leq d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) + d(\boldsymbol{y},\boldsymbol{z})\) for any \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}, \boldsymbol{z} \in \boldsymbol{X}\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• Metrics are always nonnegative. The only point at a zero distance from a point \(\boldsymbol{x}\) is \(\boldsymbol{x}\) itself.
  • Metrics are symmetric and adhere to the triangle inequality.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The Euclidean distance in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is defined as \(\displaystyle d(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}) = \left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2\right)^{1/2}\text{.}\)
  • The complex numbers \(\mathbb{C}\) with the distance function (based on modulus) \(d(z,w) = |z-w|\) form a metric space.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
A norm on a vector space \(\boldsymbol{V}\) over the scalar field \(\mathbb{F}\) (commonly \(\mathbb{R}\)) is a function \(\|\cdot\|\colon \boldsymbol{V}\to[0,+\infty)\) that adheres to the following criteria:

  1. Non-negativity and definiteness: For any \(\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{V}\), \(\|\boldsymbol{x}\| \geq 0\), and \(\|\boldsymbol{x}\| = 0\) if and only if \(\boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{0}\).
  2. Positive homogeneity: For any scalar \(c \in \mathbb{F}\) and any \(\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{V}\), \(\|c\boldsymbol{x}\| = |c|\cdot\|\boldsymbol{x}\|\).
  3. Triangle inequality: For any \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \boldsymbol{V}\): \(\|\boldsymbol{x} + \boldsymbol{y}\| \leq \|\boldsymbol{x}\| + \|\boldsymbol{y}\|\).

A normed vector space \((\boldsymbol{V}, \|\cdot\|)\) is a vector space \(\boldsymbol{V}\) over the scalar field \(\mathbb{F}\) (commonly \(\mathbb{R}\)), equipped with a norm \(\|\cdot\|\).

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • Given a normed vector space \((\boldsymbol{V}, \|\cdot\|)\), one can define the metric as \(d(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) = \|\boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\|,\) making \((\boldsymbol{V}, d)\) inherently a metric space.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The real line \(\mathbb{R}\) with the absolute-value norm forms a normed vector space over \(\mathbb{R}\).
  • The plane \(\mathbb{R}^2\) with the Euclidean norm is similarly a normed vector space. Using the taxicab norm, \(\mathbb{R}^2\) remains a normed vector space.

docs.title: Open and Closed Sets in a Metric Space
📘 Definition
docs.text:
For a metric space \((\boldsymbol{X},d)\) and its subset \(\boldsymbol{E}\):

  • \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is closed if it includes all of its boundary points, i.e., \(\partial \boldsymbol{E} \subseteq \boldsymbol{E}\).
  • \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is open if it doesn't include any of its boundary points, i.e., \(\partial \boldsymbol{E} \cap \boldsymbol{E} = \varnothing\).
  • \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is neither open nor closed if it includes some but not all of its boundary points.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• A set \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is open if and only if \(\boldsymbol{E} = \mathrm{int}\boldsymbol{E}\).
  • A set \(\boldsymbol F\) is closed if and only if every convergent sequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_i)_{i=1}^{\infty}\) within \(\boldsymbol{F}\) converges to a limiting point lying in \(\boldsymbol{F}\).
  • A set \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is open if and only if its complement \(\boldsymbol{E}^\complement=\boldsymbol{X}\setminus \boldsymbol{E}\) is closed.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text: • The open metric ball \(\boldsymbol{B}(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \varepsilon)\) is open.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
For a metric space \((\boldsymbol{X},d)\), a point \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) in \(\boldsymbol{X}\), and \(r > 0\), the open metric ball \(\boldsymbol{B}_{(\boldsymbol{X},d)}(\boldsymbol{x}_0,r)\) in \(\boldsymbol{X}\), centered at \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) with radius \(r\) in metric \(d\), is defined as the following set:

\[ \boldsymbol{B}_{(\boldsymbol{X},d)}(\boldsymbol{x}_0,r) = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{X} \colon d(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}_0) < r\}. \]

If the context is clear, we'll abbreviate this as \(\boldsymbol{B}_d(\boldsymbol{x}_0,r)\) or simply \(\boldsymbol{B}(\boldsymbol{x}_0,r).\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Let \(\boldsymbol{x}=(x_1,x_2, \ldots,x_n)\in\mathbb{R}^n\). For \(p\in[1,+\infty]\), the \(\boldsymbol{p}\)-norm, denoted \(\|\cdot\|_p\), is defined on \(\mathbb{R}^n\) by:

\[ \|\boldsymbol{x}\|_p = \left(\sum_{i=1}^n |x_i|^p\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}. \]

Correspondingly, the \(p\)-metric \(d_p\) is defined as

\[ d_p(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y)=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n |x_i-y_i|^p\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}. \]

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • The smallest permissible value for \(p\) in the \(p\)-norm is \(1\).

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The Euclidean distance \(d_2\) is a particular \(p\)-metric when \(p=2\).
  • The taxicab distance \(d_1\) is a particular \(p\)-metric when \(p=1\).
  • The maximum norm \(\|\cdot\|_\infty\) is a particular \(p\)-norm when \(p=+\infty\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: In the metric space \((\boldsymbol{X}, d_{\boldsymbol{X}})\text{,}\) a subset \(\boldsymbol{E}\) is termed path-connected if, for any two distinct points \(\boldsymbol{a}, \boldsymbol{b} \in \boldsymbol{E}\text{,}\) a path \(\boldsymbol{p}\colon [0,1] \to \boldsymbol{E}\) exists such that \(\boldsymbol{p}(0) = \boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{p}(1) = \boldsymbol{b}\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • In the metric space \((\boldsymbol{X}, d_{\boldsymbol{X}})\text{,}\) any path-connected subset of \(\boldsymbol{X}\) is connected.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text: • The topologist's sine curve is connected but not path-connected: $$ {(0,0)}\cup {(x,\sin (1/x)) \colon x\in (0,+\infty)}. $$

docs.text: Let \((f_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}\) be a sequence of functions \(f_n\colon X_n\to \mathbb{R}\) and \(f\colon X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) be another function. We say that \((f_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}\) converges pointwise to \(\boldsymbol{f}\) on \(\boldsymbol{X}\) and write \(f_n\to f\text{,}\) if for every \(x \in X\text{,}\) \(\displaystyle \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f_n(x) = f(x)\text{.}\)

  • \(f_n(x) = \dfrac{n}{nx + 1}\) converges pointwise to \(f(x)=1/x\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
The polar coordinate system specifies a given point in a plane by using two coordinates:

  • the point's distance from a reference point called the pole,
  • the point's direction from the pole relative to the direction of the polar axis, a ray drawn from the pole.

The distance from the pole is called the radius, and the angle is called the polar angle.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \(a \in \mathbb{R}\text{.}\) A power series centered at \(\boldsymbol{a}\) is expressed as \(\displaystyle\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\text{,}\) where \((c_n)_{n=0}^\infty\) is a sequence of real numbers, independent of \(x\text{.}\) We refer to \(c_n\) as the \(\boldsymbol{n}\)-th coefficient of the power series.

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: This is the formal definition of power series since it is not discussed whether such a series is convergent or divergent for different \(x\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text: The area of the square whose side is the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) is equal to the sum of the areas of the squares on the other two sides. The theorem can be written as an equation relating the lengths of the sides \(a\), \(b\) and the hypotenuse \(c\), sometimes called the Pythagorean equation: $$ a^2+b^2=c^2. $$

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: For a given power series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\text{,}\) its radius of convergence \(R\) is a nonnegative real number or \(+\infty\) such that the series converges if \(|x-a|<R\) and diverges if \(|x-a|>R\text{.}\) The interval of convergence is the set of all values of \(x\) for which the series converges.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • The convergence of \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\) at \(x=a-R\) and \(x=a+R\) is to be determined case-by-case.

docs.title: 📌 Proposition
docs.text: Consider the power series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x - a)^n\text{.}\) The radius of convergence \(R\) can be found using \(\displaystyle R = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{c_{n}}{c_{n+1}} \right|\) if the limit exists or tends to infinity.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n!}\) converges for all \(x\in\mathbb{R}\) since \(\displaystyle R=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{(n+1)!}{n!} \right|=+\infty\text{.}\)
  • \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^n(x-3)^n\) converges for \(|x-3|<1/2\) since \(\displaystyle R=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{2^{n}}{2^{n+1}} \right|=\dfrac{1}{2}\text{.}\)
  • \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty n!(x+1)^n\) diverges for all \(x\) except \(x=-1\) since \(\displaystyle R=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{n!} {(n+1)!}\right|=0\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📌 Proposition
docs.text:
Consider the series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n\) where \(a_n\in\mathbb{R}\text{.}\) Let \(\displaystyle L=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{a_{n+1}}{a_n} \right|\text{,}\) then:

  • If \(L < 1\text{,}\) the series converges. Moreover, \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty |a_n|\) also converges.
  • If \(L > 1\text{,}\) the series diverges.
  • If \(L = 1\) or the limit does not exist, the test is inconclusive.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n}{\mathrm{e}^n}\) is convergent since \(\displaystyle L=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{(n+1)/\mathrm{e}^{n+1}}{n/\mathrm{e}^n} \right| =\dfrac{1}{\mathrm{e}}<1\text{.}\)
  • \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n}{n}\) diverges since \(\displaystyle L=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \dfrac{2^{n+1}/(n+1)}{2^n/n} \right| =2>1\text{.}\)
  • When \(L=1\text{,}\) both convergent and divergent series exist, e.g., \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n}\) diverges while \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^2}\) converges.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
Let \(f\colon E \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function where \(E \subseteq \mathbb{R}\text{.}\) We say:

  • \(f\) is real analytic at \(\boldsymbol{x=a}\) if \(a\) is an interior point of \(E\) and there exists a power series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\) centered at \(a\) and an open interval \((a-r, a+r) \subseteq E\) (for some \(r > 0\)) where this series converges to \(f\text{.}\)
  • \(f\) is real analytic on \(\boldsymbol{E}\) if \(E\) is an open set and \(f\) is real analytic at every point \(a \in E\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• The convergence type here is not limited, but if we consider a closed subinterval of \((a-r,a+r)\text{,}\) then it is the uniform convergence.
  • Sums, products, and compositions of real analytic functions are also real analytic.
  • A real analytic function is always infinitely differentiable, and all of its higher-order derivatives are real analytic.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• Almost all common functions are real analytic.
  • Most piecewise functions are not real analytic.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: The real coordinate space of dimension \(n\), denoted \(\mathbb {R} ^{n}\), is the set of all ordered \(n\)-tuples of real numbers.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • With component-wise addition and scalar multiplication, the real coordinate space is a real vector space.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text: • Special cases are called the real line \(\mathbb R^1\), the real coordinate plane \(\mathbb R^2\), and the real coordinate three-dimensional space \(\mathbb R^3\).

docs.title: 📌 Proposition
docs.text: The radius of convergence of a power series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n\) is given by $$ R=\frac{1}{\limsup\limits_{n\to\infty} |c_n|^{1/n}}. $$

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• If the sequence values \(|c_n|^{1/n}\) are unbounded so that its \(\limsup\) is \(+\infty\text{,}\) then the power series does not converge anywhere near \(a\text{.}\)
  • If the \(\limsup\) in the denominator is \(0\) then the radius of convergence is \(+\infty\text{,}\) meaning that the series converges on \(\mathbb{R}\text{.}\)

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty n(-2)^n (x-3)^n\) is convergent for \(|x-3|<\dfrac{1}{2}\) since \(R = \dfrac{1}{\limsup\limits_{n \to\infty}|n\left(-2\right)^{n}|^{1/n}} = \dfrac{1}{2}\text{.}\)
  • \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^{n^2} (x+2)^n\) is divergent except at \(x=-2\) since \(R= \dfrac{1}{\limsup\limits_{n \rightarrow \infty}|2^{n^{2}}|^{1/n}}= 0\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📌 Proposition
docs.text:
Consider the series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n\) where \(a_n \in \mathbb{R}\text{.}\) Let \(\displaystyle L = \limsup_{n \to \infty} \sqrt[n]{|a_n|}\text{,}\) then:

  • If \(L < 1\text{,}\) the series converges. Moreover, \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty |a_n|\) also converges.
  • If \(L > 1\text{,}\) the series diverges.
  • If \(L = 1\text{,}\) the test is inconclusive.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • One of the differences between the ratio test and the root test is that the limit in the ratio test may not exist, while the limit in the root test always exists.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n}{\mathrm{e}^n}\) is convergent since \(\displaystyle L=\limsup_{n \to \infty} \sqrt[n]{\left| \frac{n}{\mathrm{e}^n} \right|} = \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}}<1\text{.}\)
  • \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n}{n}\) diverges since \(\displaystyle L=\limsup_{n \to \infty} \sqrt[n]{\left|\frac{2^n}{n} \right|} = 2>1\text{.}\)
  • When \(L=1\text{,}\) both convergent and divergent series exist, e.g., \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n}\) diverges while \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^2}\) converges.

A subset \(\boldsymbol{E}\) of \(\boldsymbol{X}\) is termed sequentially compact if for every sequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_i)_{i=1}^\infty\) with each \(\boldsymbol{x}_i \in \boldsymbol{E}\text{,}\) there exists a convergent subsequence \((\boldsymbol{x}_{i_j})_{j=1}^\infty\) that converges to a point \(\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{E}\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \(\boldsymbol{X}\) be a metric space. The metrics \(d_p\) and \(d_q\) on \(\boldsymbol{X}\) are termed strongly equivalent, denoted \(d_p\approx d_q\), if positive constants \(a\) and \(b\) exist such that for any \(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y} \in \boldsymbol{X}\), $$ a \cdot d_p(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) \leq d_q(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}) \leq b \cdot d_p(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}). $$

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: Equivalent metrics measure distances in different scales but agree on which points are close or far apart.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• The strong equivalence relation possesses symmetry (\(d_p\approx d_q\) if and only if \(d_q\approx d_p\)), reflexivity (\(d_p\approx d_p\)) and transitivity (if \(d_p\approx d_q\) and \(d_q\approx d_r\), then \(d_p\approx d_r\)).
  • Strongly equivalent metrics induce the same notion of convergence.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• Any two \(p\)-metrics on \(\mathbb R^n\) are strongly equivalent.
  • The discrete metric, \(d_{\text{disc}}\), is not strongly equivalent to any of the \(p\)-metrics.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: If \(\boldsymbol V\) is a vector space over a field \(\mathbb F\), a subset \(\boldsymbol W\) of \(\boldsymbol V\) is a linear subspace, or simply subspace, of \(\boldsymbol V\) if \(\boldsymbol W\) is a vector space over \(\mathbb F\) for the operations of \(\boldsymbol V\). Equivalently, a subspace of \(\boldsymbol V\) is a nonempty subset \(\boldsymbol W\) such that, for \(\boldsymbol w_1, \boldsymbol w_2\in\boldsymbol W\) and \(\alpha,\beta \in \mathbb F\), we have that \(\alpha \boldsymbol w_1+\beta \boldsymbol w_2\in\boldsymbol W.\)

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: A subspace of a vector space is a subset of that vector space that is itself a vector space under the same operations.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • Subspaces are nonempty, and are closed under sums and under scalar multiples.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The singleton set consisting of the zero vector alone \(\{\boldsymbol 0\}\) and the entire vector space itself \(\boldsymbol V\) are linear subspaces that are called the trivial subspaces of the vector space \(\boldsymbol V\).
  • The real line \(\mathbb R\) is a subspace of \(\mathbb R^n\).

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
The taxicab distance between points \(\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) and \(\boldsymbol y=(y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n)\) in an \(n\)-dimensional real coordinate space \(\mathbb R^n\) with fixed Cartesian coordinate system is:

\[ d_1(\boldsymbol x,\boldsymbol y)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}|y_i-x_i|. \]

The taxicab norm of \(\boldsymbol x=(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) is calculated as:

\[ \|\boldsymbol x\|_1=\sum_{i=1}^{n}|x_i|. \]

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text: The taxicab distance represents the distance a taxi would travel between two points when restricted to cardinal directions (north, south, east, west) without moving diagonally or in any other curved path.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: The polynomial that emerges from Taylor's theorem is termed the \(\boldsymbol{k}\)-th order Taylor polynomial for the function \(f\) at \(x=a\): $$ P_{k}(x) = f(a) + f^{\prime}(a)(x-a) + \cdots + \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k !}(x-a)^{k}. $$

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text:
• The \(k\)-th order Taylor polynomial of \(f\) captures the initial \(k+1\) terms of its Taylor series (given existence) centered at the same point.
  • This polynomial stands out as the unique asymptotic best fit for the function \(f\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • The \(k\)-th order Taylor polynomial and the function \(f\) share the same derivatives up to the \(k\)-th order.

docs.text:
Let \(a\) be an interior point of \(E\subseteq \mathbb{R}\text{,}\) and let \(f\colon E\to\mathbb{R}\) be real analytic at \(x=a\text{.}\) Then \(f\) has the power series expansion around \(x=a\):

\[ f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!} (x-a)^n \quad \text{for all } x \in (a-r,a+r), \]

known as the Taylor series of \(f\) around \(x=a\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text:
Let \(k \geq 1\) be an integer and assume that the function \(f\colon \mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}\) is \(k\)-times differentiable (not necessarily real analytic) at \(x=a\text{.}\) There exists a function \(\displaystyle h_k \colon \mathbb{R} \to\mathbb{R}\) such that \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} h_k(x) = 0\) and

$$ f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \cdots + \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k !}(x-a)^k + R_k(x) $$ where \(R_k(x)= h_k(x)(x-a)^k\) is called the Peano form of the remainder.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • Using the little-\(o\) notation, the statement in Taylor's theorem reads as \(R_k(x)=o((x-a)^k)\text{,}\) as \(x\to a\text{.}\) In this case, we have the \(k\)-th order Taylor expansion: $$ f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \cdots + \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k !}(x-a)^{k} + o((x-a)^{k}). $$

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Two metrics \(d_p\) and \(d_q\) on a space \(\boldsymbol{X}\) are termed (topologically) equivalent if they produce identical topology (the set of open subsets of \(\boldsymbol{X}\)) on \(\boldsymbol{X}\), i.e., a subset \(\boldsymbol{E} \subseteq \boldsymbol{X}\) is open with respect to \(d_p\) if and only if it's open under \(d_q\). This relationship is expressed as \(d_p \sim d_q.\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text: • If two metrics are strongly equivalent, then they are topologically equivalent.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• The metric \(d_{\tan}(x,y)=|\tan x-\tan y|\) is topologically equivalent to the absolute value metric on \(\mathbb R\), but they are not strongly equivalent.
  • The discrete metric is not topologically equivalent to any \(p\)-metrics.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
A topology on a set \(\boldsymbol{X}\), often denoted by \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\), is a collection of subsets of \(\boldsymbol{X}\) that satisfies the following properties:

  1. Both the empty set and the entire set \(\boldsymbol{X}\) belong to \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\).
  2. Any union of elements in \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\) also belongs to \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\).
  3. The intersection of any finite number of elements in \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\) remains in \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\).

The pair \((\boldsymbol{X},\boldsymbol \tau)\) is called a topological space.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: A function \(f\colon X \to \mathbb{R}\) is said to be uniformly continuous if, for every \(\varepsilon >0\text{,}\) there exists a \(\delta >0\) such that for all pairs of points \(x_1, x_2\in X\) with \(|x_1-x_2|<\delta\text{,}\) it holds that \(|f(x_1)-f(x_2)|<\varepsilon\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• Every uniformly continuous function is continuous, the converse doesn't necessarily hold.
  • \(f\) is uniformly continuous on \(X\) if and only if given two equivalent sequences \((x_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) and \((y_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) in \(X\text{,}\) sequences \((f(x_n))_{n=1}^\infty\) and \((f(y_n))_{n=1}^\infty\) are also equivalent.
  • A continuous function \(f\) is uniformly continuous on \((a, b)\) if and only if the right limit \(\displaystyle f(a^+)\) and the left limit \(\displaystyle f(b^-)\) both exist and are finite.
  • A differentiable function \(f\) is uniformly continuous on \((a,b)\) if \(f'\) is bounded.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text: Let \((f_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) be a sequence of functions defined on \(X \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) and \(f\colon X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) be another function. We say that \((f_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) converges uniformly to \(\boldsymbol{f}\) on \(\boldsymbol{X}\) and write \(f_n\rightrightarrows f\text{,}\) if for every \(\varepsilon > 0\text{,}\) there exists a positive integer \(N\) such that for all \(n > N\text{,}\) the inequality \(|f_n(x) - f(x) | < \varepsilon\) holds for all \(x \in X\text{.}\)

docs.title: - Uniform convergence preserves boundedness, limits/continuity, differentiability, and integrals.
✏️ Examples
docs.text:
• \(f_n(x) = x/n\) converges uniformly to \(f(x)=0\text{.}\)
  • \(f_n(x) = \dfrac{n}{nx + 1}\) converges pointwise, but not uniformly, to \(f(x)=1/x\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
A vector space \(\boldsymbol{V}\) over a scalar field \(\mathbb{F}\) (commonly \(\mathbb{R}\) or \(\mathbb C\)) is a collection of vectors equipped with the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication that satisfy the following properties:

Let \(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y},\boldsymbol{z}\in \boldsymbol{V}\). 1. Closure under addition: \(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{y}\in\boldsymbol{V}\). 2. Associativity of addition: \(\boldsymbol{x} + (\boldsymbol{y} + \boldsymbol{z}) = (\boldsymbol{x} + \boldsymbol{y}) + \boldsymbol{z}\). 3. Additive identity: There exists a zero vector \(\boldsymbol{0}\in \boldsymbol{V}\) such that \(\boldsymbol{x} + \boldsymbol{0} = \boldsymbol{x}\). 4. Commutativity of addition: \(\boldsymbol{x} + \boldsymbol{y} = \boldsymbol{y} + \boldsymbol{x}\). 5. Additive inverse: There exists \(-\boldsymbol{x}\in\boldsymbol{V}\) such that \(\boldsymbol{x} + (-\boldsymbol{x}) = \boldsymbol{0}\). Let \(\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{F}\) and \(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in \boldsymbol{V}\). 6. Closure under scalar multiplication: \(\alpha \boldsymbol{x}\in\boldsymbol{V}\). 7. Associativity of scalar multiplication: \(\alpha(\beta\boldsymbol{x}) = (\alpha\beta)\boldsymbol{x}\). 8. Distributive property over vector addition: \(\alpha(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{y}) = \alpha\boldsymbol{x} + \alpha\boldsymbol{y}\). 9. Distributive property over scalar addition: \((\alpha+\beta)\boldsymbol{x} = \alpha\boldsymbol{x} + \beta\boldsymbol{x}\). 10. Scalar multiplication identity: For the multiplication identity \(1\in\mathbb F\), we have \(1\boldsymbol x=\boldsymbol x\).

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text: For a continuous function \(f\colon [a, b] \to \mathbb{R}\) and any \(\varepsilon > 0\text{,}\) there exists a polynomial \(P\colon [a, b]\to\mathbb{R}\) such that \(\|P-f\|_\infty < \varepsilon\text{.}\)

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• Every continuous function on \([a, b]\) can be uniformly approximated by polynomials.
  • Continuous functions over the entirety of \(\mathbb{R}\) aren't always uniformly approximable by polynomials.

docs.title: 📘 Definition
docs.text:
The Weierstrass function is defined as

$$ f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty a^n \cos(b^n x) $$ where \(0<a<1\) and \(ab>1\text{.}\)

docs.title: 🧠 Interpretation
docs.text:
The Weierstrass function is one of the most famous examples of continuous but nowhere differentiable functions. In the original paper, this function is defined as \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty a^n \cos(b^n \pi x)\) where  \(0<a<1\text{,}\) \(b\) is a positive odd number, and \(ab>1+\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\text{.}\)

The Weierstrass function is based on the earlier Riemann function \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \dfrac{\sin(n^2 x)}{n^2}\text{,}\) which has also been called the Weierstrass function.

docs.title: ⭐ Key Results
docs.text:
• The Weierstrass function is continuous everywhere as long as \(0<a<1\text{.}\)
  • The Weierstrass function is nowhere differentiable if \(ab>1\text{.}\)

docs.title: 📜 Theorem
docs.text: Suppose \((f_n)_{n=1}^\infty\) is a sequence of bounded functions on \(X\) such that the series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \|f_n\|_\infty\) converges. Then, the series \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n(x)\rightrightarrows f\text{.}\) In addition, \(f_n\)'s are continuous implies that the limiting function \(f\) is also continuous.

docs.title: ✏️ Examples
docs.text: • The series \(\displaystyle f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^n} \cos(3^n x)\) is convergent due to the Weierstrass \(M\)-test: $$ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| \frac{1}{2^n} \cos(3^n x) \right| \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^n} = 1. $$
